Award.AwardTitle: FRG: Collaborative Research: Unified statistical theory for the analysis and discovery of complex networks
Award.AbstractNarration:
The investigators will develop a unified nonparametric theoretical framework to study stochastic network models and design scalable algorithms (and software) to fit these models. They intend to carry out the development and validation of their methods with collaborators in biology who have gathered extensive new data for the assessment of protein structure and determination of biological pathways particularly in Drosophila. Such problems are omnipresent in genomics and they expect their methods to carry over widely. They will also use networks with uncertainty measures to study relationships between words and phrases in a newspaper database in order to provide media analysts with automatic and scalable algorithms. In all cases they will focus on methods of general statistical confidence which have been lacking in work so far.

Our world is connected through relationships, among "actors" who can be people, organizations, words, genes, proteins, and more. Advancements of information technology have enabled collection of massive amounts of data in all disciplines for us to build relationships between these actors. These relationships can be effectively described as networks, and properties or patterns in these networks can be random or knowledge. Responding to this recent data availability and a huge potential for knowledge discovery, research in networks is attracting much attention from researchers in physics, social science, computer science, and probability. While contributing to the development of core statistical research, the proposed research will directly impact the interdisciplinary field of network analysis and the study of complex networks. The applications of their research results are diverse and well beyond the two fields studied in the proposal: genomics and media analysis. They include national security, communications, sociology, political science, and infectious disease. The statistical tools developed are unifying and could change how many scientists approach network analysis. As a result, statistical research will become more prominent in the networks community.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goals of this Focused Research Group, centered at the University of California, Berkeley and the University of Michigan were to develop a unified mathematical framework for understanding network data and connecting the literature in the physical, biological, computer and social sciences with that in probability and statistics. The interaction between the Berkeley and Michigan groups and others was fostered by regular electronic meetings  and resulted in several research projects discussed in our final report. 

We developed and analyzed many network models and algorithms and employed them in biological applications. We studied primarily models for community detection, focusing on finding a number of meaningful clusters (communities) in networks. In the regime where the average number of edges that a node has is greater than the logarithm of the number of nodes in the network (large but not too large). We showed that computationally efficient methods could be developed for identifying all community members correctly and thus other parameters could be obtained easily. 

In particular, we proposed the StaNMF method for building local gene-gene interaction networks using spatial gene expression data from fruitfly embryos in systems biology; we designed the iterative Random Forests (iRF) algorithm for recovering high-order interactions among biomolecules; we developed a semi-supervised approach with bagging to identify context-specific pathways. All these methods provide effective ways to extract biological insights from complex and often noisy gene expression data. In work growing out of the project, led by Rachel Wang and Purna Sarkar we developed a model for analyzing 3d structure of the  genome. We also have begun developing semi-supervised computational methods to discover functional relations between gene networks.

Moreover, we introduced models for incorporating node/edge covariates (called metadata in the physics literature), overlapping communities, and nested community hierarchies, again developing provably correct and computationally efficient methods. We showed in work coming out of this project that to fit these types of models in sparse situations it might be necessary to use divide and conquer techniques PACE and GALE developed with Purna Sarkar. 

Much related research has been conducted in parallel to ours, in particular at Yale, U Penn, Johns Hopkins, and Michigan. The final FRG workshop was helpful in conjunction with the opening workshop of a 6-month program on network theory at the Isaac Newton Institute in Cambridge, UK, in July 2016.   This was a very fruitful gathering by bringing our FRG groups together with many others from around the world social scientists, physicists, Bayesian statisticians, and probabilists. The workshop had 93 participants of which 18 (all junior except for the FRG co-PIs) were partially funded by this project. A general conclusion was that in real high-dimensional applications, additional information about covariates and structural constraints on the network are critical in getting plausible solutions. A large number of graduate students and postdocs of both genders, domestic and international, were supported by and contributed to this project and together with faculty from statistics and other departments attended our weekly workshop in Berkeley in person or remotely. A substantial number of publications, presentations, and collaborations resulted from this project, and are detailed in the final report.
